ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to implement frontend and backend for simple web applications. This includes using Python and Flask.
full stack web dev
I learned the basic of the technological anatomy of a full-stack architecture.

I learned about the latest web development technologies such as HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and various frameworks that are commonly used to build web applications.

I gained knowledge of server-side programming languages and frameworks, such as PHP, Python, 

Database management: I learned about database management systems, such as MySQL, 

Front-end development: I learned how to design and implement user interfaces using modern front-end technologies, such as React.

Version control: I gained knowledge of version control systems, such as Git, and learn how to collaborate with other developers by working with branches, pull requests, and code reviews.

If you have web dev experience, it might seem like you aren't learning a lot BUT I found that I was missing a lot of small things to improve my code (i.e., I did not fully understand what I was doing or why before). The course went over Flask (Python), Javascript (JQuery & AJax too), SQL (ordinary and using SQLAlchemy), and of course HTML, CSS (and Jinja).
Great class, learnt how to build cool projects!
Full stack web programming
front end dev, back end dev, html, css, js, react, flask, everything full stack
basic, high-level web dev concepts. Sockets, I/O, server programming
Full-stack web development

I learned about, as the name suggests, full stack development. Overall, I think was a very useful and practical course -- we learned SQL, python (flask), backend client/server interactions, and frontend. It was also fully motivated in terms of the 'why', like why HTTP came around, which gives a fair amount of intuition. The PSETs helped a lot in being able to better understand the content and the project helped us apply the skills in a novel way. Even the midterm forced you to really get a good grip on the course content. I feel, for the first time, that I am able to independently code a full application. Although not all the content was directly relevant, it all gave us a great background on understanding how to do full stack.
Full stack web programming skills, teamwork experience
Flask, HTML, CSS, servers, Javascript, JQuery, AJAX etc. Lots of useful foundations to Web Development!
How to use flask, JavaScript, and a bit of react
Web development, problem solving, research for help

I learned about all aspects of web development including front end, back end, and server side. I learned how to use SQL, JavaScript, HTML, CSS, Python along with many additional libraries to assist in working with these languages.

Full stack web development with SQLite database, Flask/Python server, desktop GUI with IDE, and HTML/CSS/Javascript webpage with some JQuery and BootStrap. We also go over some other topics like React, web security, and SQL Alchemy briefly.
I learned a lot about front end and backend development. We used j query, jinja, and flask for most of the class.
Knowledge of the basics of full stack web programming, including specific languages/frameworks such as javascript (jquery) and python (flask)
JavaScript, Python, HTML/CSS, SQL, Web Development
Web programming and how to work on projects independently. Be prepared to learn more on your own apart from the class materials.
I learned various web development skills - database design, front-end with html,css,JavaScript, flask, react

By taking this course, I learned about the basics of each layer of web programming and learned how to use programming languages to work on both the front-end and back-end of web applications. Not only did I learn how to code in new languages (SQL, Python, JS, HTML/CSS, etc.), I more importantly learned how to tie everything together.
A relatively in-depth course on how full-stack projects are built!
the skill of watching youtube videos
SQLite, Flask, Pyqt6, html, css, js, bootstrap
How to make a pretty janky website using html, css and js

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: I really enjoyed the format of the midterm, and a lack of actual paper exams. I think that the hands-on approach for everything really helped me learn the content in the class, and the TAs and/or Alan were available to help with problems when they arose. I also liked the group projects, since having other people to work with made the class a lot more managable. 

Cons: The second homework, making the GUI was really frustrating, since the GUI felt like a step back from everything else the class is doing. While that pset also split the front end and backend, I think it would've been a lot less frustrating to do it without the GUI.

Very slowly progresses to full-stack principles. I don't believe we needed a pset to implement a GUI. Also very unorganized, there was no auto-grader setup for any of the psets and lectures were very slow and not too engaging.
good Psets, good lecturing
I thought the course was very good. However, I would say that for programmers who already know how to do full-stack programming, it may be a waste of time.

strengths:

Comprehensive learning: Full stack web programming courses offer comprehensive learning opportunities for students to gain knowledge in both front-end and back-end development.
Hands-on experience: Practical projects enable students to apply what they have learned in real-world scenarios.
Exposure to latest technologies: These courses cover a wide range of programming languages, frameworks, and libraries that are essential to building modern web applications.
Flexibility: Full stack web programming courses can be taken online, enabling students to learn at their own pace and convenience.
Career advancement: Learning full stack web programming can open up new career opportunities and enable professionals to advance in their careers.

Weaknesses:

Fast-paced nature of curriculum: The pace of learning can be challenging for some students, especially those who are new to programming.
Limited depth of knowledge: Covering many topics in one course can limit the depth of knowledge students acquire in any one area.
Lack of specialization: Some students may prefer to specialize in specific programming languages, frameworks, or tools but full stack web programming courses cover a wide range of topics, making it difficult to specialize.
Limited instructor feedback: Some courses may not offer regular feedback and support from instructors, making it challenging for students to identify areas where they need improvement and how to address them.
Technical difficulties: Technical issues can arise, especially with online courses, such as internet connectivity problems or issues with the learning platform.

The live coding was extremely helpful for understanding how things work (especially if you ask questions). The PSETs are enjoyable and feel like you're learning. The midterm was coding-based which was so much better than other CS classes. The final project is group-based which can make or break it.

I honestly thought the lectures were great. However, attendance was pretty low (and it's hard to get the most out of it without going to lectures) so I am sure that will affect other people's ratings.
Did not have a wonderful experience with the midterm. Instead, I wish we had more time to have a 24-hour midterm so we could resolve any potential issues that would arise.

strengths - good psets and the final project was fun. weaknesses - lectures weren't the most helpful, doesn't teach up-to-date technologies (no react, still using flask+python), and lack of guidance on the final project.

strengths: really good progression of topics that build on top of each other
weaknesses: none

strengths: some of the high level lectures are quite okay. They have good content of what web programming looks like
weaknesses: a lot of the technologies used are dated. The PSETs are alright, but somewhat unnecessary and don't line up well with course covered content. We spend a lot of time learning syntax for Python and JS. The final project is poorly structured since it relies on ULAs to manage them.

Strengths: PSETs were great in terms of scope, and pair programming is always nice when not a lot of CS courses do the same. Alan is a good lecturer who takes time to explain material, although he's not great at checking emails so post questions on ed instead. The participation point encouraged me to watch lecture online if not in person. The midterm grading was also very generous considering you could resubmit for half points. 
Weaknesses: The midterm was a little too similar to the PSETs, I wish the database was a little smaller and different so we had to test our SQL skills there instead of copying code over. The grading was also a little slow at the start. Otherwise, great course!
Course materials are informative and practical, and assignments are very relevant and instructional.

Strengths:
- Alan is a good lecturer and a kind professor. The course is overall well-organized
- The ULAs are also great but depending on who your ULA is, you could receive pretty different grades on the PSet to someone who as the same PSet as you
- Very practical course and great introduction to a lot of web-app technologies

Weaknesses:
- Definitely need to hold more Office Hours. OH were only held twice a week over a 2 hour period in the evening on weekdays, making it difficult for people to attend.
- Clearer specs for the Problem Sets and preferably demo videos for all of them
- Faster grading for all the assignments -- only the midterm was graded at a reasonable time.

Assignments were interesting but the specs were not very precise and often lacked clarification. For later psets, it would be helpful if there was a section that specified the differences between the current pset and the previous pset.

Strengths: Very well structured for learning

Weaknesses: N/A

Strengths include that the material we covered was interesting and useful outside of class. I think wen development is an important skill for all cs majors to have. I found the times midterm to be a little difficult as one bug could stop u from completing the exam and did not feel it to be an accurate representation of my skills. I also appreciated the group work element of this class which really helped me improve my use of git and GitHub.

The course is well taught and the lectures are easy to understand, and the project-based assignments are really helpful for learning the topics. Being able to work in groups for the projects and problem sets is also very helpful since it splits up the large time requirement. The psets could be better specified, and the midterm quiz felt a bit out of place since writing even a simple full-stack app in 75 minutes is very difficult.
The organization of the class was really great and the lectures were amazing. I think the psets were really fair and evenly paced, and even the midterm quiz was very doable.

Strengths: assignments were pretty interesting
Weaknesses: grading of assignments was often inconsistent and nitpicky at times

Less focus on Python and more focus on JavaScript since JavaScript is a lot harder to master.

More active feedback on project milestones.
This course all and all was pretty good. I learned very useful things, the assignments were good and so were the lectures.

This course had several strengths: all of the skills learned in lecture are applied to make a web application through the homework assignments, the course staff are helpful and supportive, the final project followed a good timeline throughout the semester and helped me realize how much I had learned throughout the course.

Strengths: Final project was fun

Weaknesses: The first problem set assumed a lot of prerequisite software engineering knowledge that are not taught in lower level CS classes

Very interesting for someone who has no background in fullstrack. Lectures covered an interesting breadth. Psets werent too challenging though which was a shame. Well designed to build on each other, but definitely could have been 1 week psets after the first couple. I wish more feedback was given on psets or perhaps a working example after the pset is due like OOP does because I never could tell if my sqlite queries were optimized.Grading isnt too harsh to make up for this though. Lots of opportunities to learn which is amazing. Midterm is a toughie even if you have been keeping up and understanding lectures/psets if you dont have prior knowledge. Only students with background did well, but there was a makeup option which was very fair in my opinion. I wish we couldve sped up pset timeline earlier so that we could have gotten more hands on experience with more modern tech or nuanced executions. Final project is a fun opportunity but can be a little bit of an overhanging stressor since its hard to motivate spending time on it without the schedule. Even then, its easy to ignore the final project when it is a really cool idea. Try and put regulat time into it, but if you cant you will still do fine

This course would be better if it taught tools that are actually used like React js, bootstrap, etc. I wish I came out of this class feeling like I could make a deployable website today but honestly watching youtube tutorials on building websites might be better than taking a course. I wish the lectures had felt more engaging and I'm not sure how to make them better. Perhaps Full Stack as a class just isn't that interesting of a topic?

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you have a friend who's also interested in taking it, yeah. Going in with a few other people is advisable because the psets and final project are all group projects. Even if you don't have a friend in the class, I think the content is enough to recommend it. The workload picks up a bit near the end of the semester, but you're done with the class before reading period begins.
Yes, very good CS elective and Alan is great
I would recommend this course to all programmers who do not have any experience with web development.
I would recommend this course to another student because this course gives a real-life experience in web development.
If you have a lot of web dev experience, it might seem like a "waste," but I found that it was a fun class to balance with other CS classes and it made me a lot more polished in my coding.
Yes, lovely class!
Yes, it was mainly self-guided, but you learn a lot.
yes, very useful

I would recommend if you need an easy CS elective. If you want to learn web programming, you're better off doing it on your own honestly. You can learn more up to date technologies, and you can learn the concepts covered in class without much hassle since there isn't a high barrier to entry. However, if you want a chill class, would recommend.
It's ok, good for a CS elective.

I would definitely recommend this course -- out of all the courses I've taken in the CS department, this has been my favorite and has really sparked my love for programming again. It was very engaging and relevant and I think I walked out of it with practical skills I can use without excessive stress.
Yes, very hands-on and practical course on full stack web programming, and excellent instructor as well.
Yes!! Definitely. The most practical CS course I have taken at Yale and a very doable elective. You get a lot from this course and I'd highly recommend.
Yes, I enjoyed working on the psets and learned a good amount

The course was really helpful in making me understand the whole process of deploying a full web app solution. The class builds from the ground up, which is really helpful as it doesn't assume working knowledge in the tech stack used. I really enjoyed it!!!

I would if you are interested in learning about web dev. If you already feel you are an expert in this topic I might skip this class, but I havent done we dev since high school and it was great learning about concepts Formally that I had self taught myself a long time ago.
Yes if you are interested in website development, but be prepared to put in a good amount of time into the class.

I would definitely recommend this to a student who doesnt have a lot of experience working in group cs projects and doesnt have a lot of experience in web dev. I didnt come in with a lot of knowledge and even though there was a learning curve for sure, I never felt overwhelmed. Also- make sure you have a good partner for your psets!
I would recommend if they want to do a group project

Yes! Really good to get your hands on web programming if you want to go into industry. This course does a good job at introducing that. However, if you want to go more in depth with frameworks like React you will have to explore it on your own through the final project. Overall still a very good course that helps you understand SQL and how that connects to the frontend with HTML/CSS & JavaScript.
Yes. If interested in web programming.
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn web development.

I would recommend this course to another student if they want to learn the fundamentals of web programming. For students who already have a lot of experience with web programming, they may not get as much out of the class as this course briefly covered all aspects of creating a web application.
meh

Only if you are totally new to the concepts. I learnt so much and it was really exciting, but if you have background you may be frustrated with pace or lack of modern frameworks taught. Definitely recommend if you have no background though as I feel like i get the basics now and it wasnt too hard to pick up because of good lecture and pset design
I would not recommend this course to another student. It didn't make me feel like the content was meaningful, so I didn't feel engaged.
